Properties of eigenvalues and eigenvectors

There are a number of general properties of eigenvalues and eigenvectors which you should be familiar with. You will be able to use them as a check on some of your calculations. 

Property 1: Sum of eigenvalues

For any square matrix \(A\): 

\(\quad\)sum of eigenvalues \(=\) sum of diagonal terms of \(A\) (called the trace of \(A\))

Formally, for an \(n\times n\) matrix \(A\): \(\qquad \displaystyle{\sum_{i=1}^n \lambda_i=\ \text{ trace} (A)}\)

(Repeated eigenvalues must be counted according to their multiplicity.)
Thus if \(\lambda_1=4, \lambda_2=4, \lambda_3=1\) then \(\displaystyle{\sum_{i=1}^{3}\lambda_i=9}\)).

Property 2: Product of eigenvalues

For any square matrix \(A\): 

\(\quad\)product of eigenvalues \(=\) determinant of \(A\)

Formally: \(\displaystyle{\qquad \lambda_1\lambda_2\lambda_3\cdots\lambda_n=\prod_{i=1}^n \lambda_i=\text{ det}(A)}\)

The symbol \(\prod\) simply denotes multiplication, as \(\sum\) denotes summation.

Example

Verify Properties 1 and 2 for the \(3\times 3\) matrix:

\(\qquad A = \left[\begin{array}{rrr}2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{array}\right]\)

whose eigenvalues were found earlier.

Solution

The three eigenvalues for this matrix are:

\(\qquad \lambda_1=2-\sqrt{2},\qquad \lambda_2=2,\qquad \lambda_3=2+\sqrt{2}.\)

Therefore

\(\qquad \lambda_1+\lambda_2+\lambda_3=(2-\sqrt{2})+2+(2+\sqrt{2})=6=\text{trace}(A),\)

whilst

\(\qquad \lambda_1\lambda_2\lambda_3=(2-\sqrt{2})(2)(2+\sqrt{2})=4=\text{det}(A).\)

Property 3: Linear independence of eigenvectors

Eigenvectors of a matrix \(A\) corresponding to distinct eigenvalues are linearly independent i.e. one eigenvector cannot be written as a linear sum of the other eigenvectors. The proof of this result is omitted but we illustrate this property with two examples.

We saw earlier that the matrix 

\(\qquad A=\left[\begin{array}{cc}1&0\\ 1&2\end{array}\right]\)

has distinct eigenvalues \(\lambda_1=1\qquad \lambda_2=2\) with associated eigenvectors

\(\qquad \underline{x_1}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ -1\end{array}\right]\qquad \underline{x_2}=\left[\begin{array}{r}0\\ 1\end{array}\right]\)

respectively. 

Clearly \(\underline{x_1}\) is not a constant multiple of \(\underline{x_2}\) and these eigenvectors are linearly independent. 

We also saw that the \(3\times 3\) matrix 

\(\qquad A=\left[\begin{array}{rrr}2&-1&0\\ -1&2&-1\\ 0&-1&2\end{array}\right]\)

had the following distinct eigenvalues  \(\lambda_1=2-\sqrt{2},\ \lambda_2=2,\ \lambda_3=2+\sqrt{2}\)  with corresponding eigenvectors of the form shown: \(\qquad \underline{x_1}=\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ \sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right],\qquad \underline{x_2}=\left[\begin{array}{r}1\\0\\-1\end{array}\right],\qquad \underline{x_3}=\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\ -\sqrt{2}\\ 1\end{array}\right]\)

Clearly none of these eigenvectors is a constant multiple of any other. Nor is any one obtainable as a linear combination of the other two. The three eigenvectors are linearly independent.

Property 4: Eigenvalues of diagonal matrices

A \(2\times 2\) diagonal matrix \(D\) has the form

\(\qquad D=\left[\begin{array}{cc}a&0\\ 0&d\end{array}\right]\)

The characteristic equation

\(\quad |D-\lambda I|=0\) is \(\left|\begin{array}{cc}a-\lambda&0\\ 0&d-\lambda\end{array}\right|=0\) 

i.e. \(\qquad (a-\lambda)(d-\lambda)=0\)

So the eigenvalues are simply the diagonal elements \(a\) and \(d\).

Similarly a \(3\times 3\) diagonal matrix has the form

\(\qquad D=\left[\begin{array}{ccc}a&0&0\\ 0&b&0\\ 0&0&c\end{array}\right]\)

having characteristic equation

\(\qquad |D-\lambda I|=(a-\lambda)(b-\lambda)(c-\lambda)=0\)

so again the diagonal elements are the eigenvalues.

We can see that a diagonal matrix is a particularly simple matrix to work with. In addition to the eigenvalues being obtainable immediately by inspection it is exceptionally easy to multiply diagonal matrices.
